titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edward Scott-Snell papersM3007
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Sharlene Disla and Lora Davis from information compiled by Joscelyn Godwin

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections and University Archives, Colgate University Libraries

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit2013-03-07T16:51-0500

did.unittitle: Edward Scott-Snell papers

repository.corpname: Special Collections and University Archives, Colgate University Libraries

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: After emigrating to the USA in 1948, Edward and Stephani Godwin lived in Woodstock, New York, and worked as authors and illustrators until their separation and divorce in 1955.

bibliography.head: Books by other authors, illustrated by Edward and Stephani Godwin:
bibliography.bibref: Bowie, W.R.The Bible Story for Boys and Girls: New Testament. New York: Abingdon-Cokesbury, 1951.
Bowie, W.R.The Bible Story for Boys and Girls: Old Testament. New York: Abingdon-Cokesbury, 1951.
Daringer, Helen Fern.Country Cousin. New York: Harcourt, Brace, 1951.
Daringer, Helen Fern.Debbie of the Green Gate. New York: Harcourt, Brace, 1950.
Daringer, Helen F.The Keepsake Ring. New York: Harcourt, Brace, 1953.
Deucher, Sibyl.The Young Brahms. New York: Dutton, 1949.
Eyre, Katherine Wigmore.Another Spring: the story of Lady Jane Grey. New York: Oxford University Press, 1949.
Eyre, Katherine Wigmore.The Song of a Thrush. New York: Henry Z. Walck, 1952.
Lau, Josephine Sanger.The Story of Joseph. New York: Abingdon-Cokesbury, 1950.
Meigs, Elizabeth Bleecker.The Crusade and the Cup. New York: Dutton, 1952.
Trachsel, Myrtle J.Elizabeth of the Mayflower. New York: Macmillan , 1950.
Walt Disney's Bear Country. Racine: Whitman, 1954.

bibliography.head: Books written and illustrated by Edward and Stephani Godwin:
bibliography.bibref: The Greenwood Tree: A Portrait of William Shakespeare. New York: Dutton, 1950.
Roman Eagle. New York: Oxford University Press, 1951.
Out of the Strong. New York: Oxford University Press, 1955.

The Kerlan Collection of Children's Literature at the University of Minnesota Libraries holds the manuscripts of two further novels,Brutus(accepted by O.U.P. but never published) andDion, as well as copies of publications by other authors.
A Child's Book of Butterflies. New York: Maxton, 1956. (Edward Godwin's last published work, the text written by his second wife, Elizabeth Bridges)

prefercite.head: Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item (Author, Title, and Date of item if known)], M3007, Edward Scott-Snell papers, Special Collections and University Archives, Colgate University Libraries.

did.unittitle: Letters to Edward Scott-Snell

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About 500 letters, filed in alphabetical order, represent Edward's life during his undergraduate years at Christ Church, Oxford (attended 1930-1933) and the activities of his friends for several years afterwards. Taken as a whole, they give insight into the daily life and concerns of an undergraduate striving for success in society and in the arts. Among the interesting subdivisions are a number of letters relating to the English Club. This was a club run by undergraduates in 1931-1933 with the assistance of the poet Edmund Blunden, which invited prominent literary figures to come and speak. The President was Richard Rumbold, notorious for his undergraduate noveLittle Victims, 1933, and later a biographer of Antoine de Saint-Exupery. Edward Scott-Snell was the secretary. The collection contains letters to Edward from Lord Berners; Laurence Binyon; Edmund Blunden; John Buchan; Lady Dunsany (3 letters, Lord Dunsany was a speaker at the Club); Louis Golding (2 letters); Christopher Hassall; Rose Macaulay (2 letters); John Masefield; May Morris (daughter of William Morris); Beverley Nichols; A.W. Pollard; Michael Sadler; Edith Sitwell; Osbert Sitwell (2 letters); and Una Troubridge (2 letters, she writes on behalf of Radclyffe Hall).

Other correspondents of literary interest are the poet, Walter de la Mare (14 letters), who became quite friendly with Edward and his mother; Hector Bolitho (12 letters), a prolific historian and royal biographer; Rev. Montague Summers (4 letters), author of books on witchcraft and the occult; "Gug" Kolkhorst (4 letters), whose Sunday morning parties for aesthetic undergraduates are celebrated in John Betjeman's autobiographical poemSummoned by Bells; and Lady Lillah Keeble, formerly the Shavian actress Lillah McCarthy (4 letters), who mentionsEdward and the English Club in her memoirs,Myself and Friends.

The collection also contains sequences of letters to Edward Scott-Snell from his closest friends. These letters are unique for their literary quality, aesthetic sensibility, affection, and the picture they give of life in the 1930s in England and abroad, especially in Italy. This series includes letters from Serge de Borchgrave (11 letters), a Belgian aristocrat and aesthete, who writes of his experiences as a draftee into the Belgian army; Archibald Colquhoun (8 letters), an artist who became a professional translator of Italian literature including works by Manzoni, Calvino, Lampedusa, etc.; Ian Greenless (13 letters), friend of the Sitwells and the homosexual-literary demimonde, later a biographer of Norman Douglas; Rodney Hindle (14 letters), a jeweller in Halifax who commissioned a bookplate from Edward; Hedley Hope-Nicholson (38 letters), an older Christ Church man, barrister, and author of the anthology,The Mind's Delight(1928) who had family connections with the Wildes and Troubridges; and Roger Venables (33 letters), Edward's closest friend, poet (especially on Cornish themes), traveller with Edward, and eloquent correspondent.

A series of ninety-four letters to Edward Scott-Snell from his mother, Margaret Scott-Snell, provides a host of insights into the family's financial conditions, travels, and attempts to further Edward's career in Oxford and after. Although all undated, they permit an approximate reconstruction of Edward's movements, travels, and activities. There are also seventeen letters from Edward's grandfather Sir Arthur Fell (1850-1934). Fell, born in New Zealand and educated at St. John's College, oxford, was a financier and politician, standing as a Tory Member of Parliament, where he worked especially to promote building the Channel Tunnel, an idea that was shelved at the outbreak of WWI. These and the other family letters are a social document illustrating an English family's decline through the generations, from the wealthy, self-made patriarch, through his divorcee daughter Margaret, whom he supported in a small house near his Wimbledon mansion, to the gifted but financially unpromising Edward, all against a background of the 1930s, the Slump, and the shadows of war.

Early educational and professional activities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes several items from Edward Scott-Snell's early educational and professional life.

First, several items document Edward's undergraduate life, including Edward's bank book (1930-1935), which records all his income and expenditures, bills, police sumons, Edward's futile search for employment after his graduation from Oxford, and his enrollment in the Slade School of Art of the University of London, 1933-1934.

Materials related to Edward's first one-man exhibition at Ryman's Oxford, 1936, are also present and include an illustrated catalogue and the list of forty-nine pictures sold with prices. Present ownership and location of these items are noted when known.

Another grouping of materials documents the rise and fall of Houghton & Scott-Snell, Ltd., a publishing company formed with the help of capital from Edward's mother, Margaret Scott-Snell (and perhaps from Sir Arthur Fell). The company survived from 1933-1937 and published about a dozen titles. Some had jacket illustrations by Edward, and two were illustrated by him throughout: John F. Macpherson'sPeter, Pam, and the Wizardand Evangeline Deverell'sAlan Singh, or The Land of Magic.

Edward worked from 1937-1948 as a teacher in publice (i.e. private) schools. Included in this series are testimonials from school and college principals, documenting his attendance at King's School, Wimbledon, and at art schools (Ruskin School of Art, Slade School of Art, Byam Shaw School of Art), and his teaching (Radley, Rugby, Christ's Hospital, Merchant Taylors). A letter acknowledging Edward's donation to the Radley College Archives of a water-color design for a rose-garden is also found in this series.

Early Creative Work

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series comprises drawings and sketches by Edward Scott-Snell, 1925-1937. There are 130 items in this collection, ranging from small sketches and paintings in wash to fully finished drawings. Together they demonstrate Edward's growth as an artist from his teenage years through his many contributions to Oxford'sIsisandCherwellmagazines, and after that as a book illustrator for his own publishing company, Houghton & Scott-Snell, Ltd.

did.unittitle: See list of possible drawings inside box
At Kelmscott Manor

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Edward's mother, Margaret Scott-Snell, made friends with May Morris, daughter of William Morris, who lived in Kelmscott Manor with her companion Miss Lobb. On May Morris's death, the manor was left to Oxford University for the use of artists. Edward Scott-Snell and his mother were the first tenants, and the manor was Edward's home exclusively from 1943-1948. In 1940 he married Stephani Allfree (born 1917), the daughter of Lt. Geoffrey S. Allfree, R[oyal] B[ritish] A[rtist] (1889-1918). She was later known as a painter and poet under the name of "Godwin." Edward and Stephani's sons Felix (1941) and Joscelyn (1945) were born during this period.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs, letters, and papers relating to Kelmscott, and specimens of Edward and Stephani's literary and artistic work from their time there, notably their jointly-written and illustrated life of William Morris,Warrior Bard(1947). This work was their first publication after they changed their surname from Scott-Snell to Godwin. Also found in this seires isThessyros, a book of poems written and illustrated by Stephani, which contain keys to the mysterious imagery of her and Edward's paintings of the Kelmscott period.

Also found in this series are a prospectus for a boarding school for young boys, which Edward and Stephani ran at the manor and a catalogue of Edward and Stephani Godwin's exhibition at Ryman's, Oxford (October 1944), which presented the fruit of their wartime years at Kelmscott. Fifty-three pictures were sold at this exhibition, while most of the rest were lost, after having been deposited in the 1950s with a Fr. Martin Leahy in Brooklyn.

Copies of Martin Knowles's geneological studies and family trees are also included in this series. These studies explain the relationships of the Scott-Snells, Fells, and others, and provide researchers with valuable infomation about these families. A booklet by Edward's aunt Winifred Whitehead, entitledWimbledon 1885-1965, contains photographs of Sir Arthur Fell and his family at Lauriston House (since destroyed). The gardens of Lauriston House and the life that was lived there were a permanent element in Edward's imagination.
